member.preliminary: This documentation will change at a moment's notice

summary.p: This documentation will show up as the summary of a class , when the UseNamespaceDocSummaries configuration flag is set to . When UseNamespaceDocSummaries is set to , the summary will show up as the summary of the namespace.

This allows you to reference other types from within the summary documentation for the namespace, without having to use fully qualified ids. E.g. the reference to is created by using "<see cref="Class"/>" instead of "<see cref="T:NDoc.Test.Class"/>" as you have to say using the namespace summaries dialog.

member.name: T:NDoc.Test.Class
member.remarks: Conceptualizing random endpoints in a access matrix provides reach extentions enterprise wide. Respective divisions historically insignificant, upscale trendlines in a management inventory analysis survivabilty format.

member.name: T:NDoc.Test.NotesTest
member.summary: This class uses note elements on its members.

summary.note: This is a test of a note tag which has lots of text in it and so should, if we are lucky, wrap to more than one line. To ensure this, here is another extremely long sentence that is probably gramatically incorrect and may have terrible spelling, but who cares, it is long isn't it?

member.name: T:NDoc.Test.EcmaBlocks
member.summary: This class has ecma block tags in the remarks

remarks.block: This is a test of an ECMA "note" block tag which has lots of text in it and so should, if we are lucky, wrap to more than one line. To ensure this, here is another extremely long sentence that is probably gramatically incorrect and may have terrible spelling, but who cares, it is long isn't it?

This is a test of an ECMA "example" block tag which has lots of text in it and so should, if we are lucky, wrap to more than one line. To ensure this, here is another extremely long sentence that is probably gramatically incorrect and may have terrible spelling, but who cares, it is long isn't it?

This is a test of an ECMA "behaviors" block tag which has lots of text in it and so should, if we are lucky, wrap to more than one line. To ensure this, here is another extremely long sentence that is probably gramatically incorrect and may have terrible spelling, but who cares, it is long isn't it?

This is a test of an ECMA "overrides" block tag which has lots of text in it and so should, if we are lucky, wrap to more than one line. To ensure this, here is another extremely long sentence that is probably gramatically incorrect and may have terrible spelling, but who cares, it is long isn't it?

This is a test of an ECMA "usage" block tag which has lots of text in it and so should, if we are lucky, wrap to more than one line. To ensure this, here is another extremely long sentence that is probably gramatically incorrect and may have terrible spelling, but who cares, it is long isn't it?

This is a test of an ECMA "default" block tag which has lots of text in it and so should, if we are lucky, wrap to more than one line. To ensure this, here is another extremely long sentence that is probably gramatically incorrect and may have terrible spelling, but who cares, it is long isn't it?
